Ashot Petrosian wrote:

>[...]
>  
>
> The mutation could still be neutral though in the sense in that it 
> doesn't affect the network, just set the weight of the connection to 
> the node to 0. I do see how we are immediately biased towards that 
> connection versus others. Perhaps instead then we can just add the 
> node originally, but increase the chances of this node getting a 
> connection substantially in the next several generation(s), or 
> something like that, otherwise we are wasting time optimizing weights 
> and a bias that has no meaning, not to mention increasing the 
> probability of bloat.

I seem to recall that Ken's NEAT does exactly that - is biased towards 
selecting nodes with higher innovation ID's (one's on the end of the 
node list).


>>>        Along the same lines of thinking, has anyone tried using more
>>>powerful functions at the nodes rather than just a threshold? For
>>>example an average, or maximum, or minimum, or a switch, or so on?
>>>      
>>>
>>We discussed this as well and I believe some people started to try it.  I
>>plan to try it.  I'm not sure "more powerful" functions are the most
>>important angle, however, I think just a choice of different simple
>>functions can be useful.  Look for a discussion about how hard it is to
>>evolve a network that multiplies two inputs...
>>    
>>
I started looking into this and it's pretty near the top o fmy list of 
things to do. I will be trying neurons with multiple connection points, 
each point sums it's inputs and each point's signal then become a 
parameter into an activation function. This allows the function to do 
all kinds of things, but I think the key is to not go overboard, keep it 
simple - perhaps try two connection points to start with, so one could 
just define the steepness of a sigmoid for instance. Before I attempt 
this though I need good/fast benchmarks, hence my particualr interest in 
that subject right now.


>>I think so.  But note that the traditional function is not that accurate
>>anyway and that biology does use several types of neurone.
>>    
>>
"ANN's are a gross oversimplification of bioligal NN's"  is another way 
of putting it :) Well that's the viewpoint I've settled on... for now :)


>
>
>By functions here I meant abilities.  For example right now it is difficult for the NN to take the negation of an output (which can actually be achieved with a linear activation function), or to choose one output from a set, or to choose the maximum of a set of outputs (Joe mentioned the idea of competitive connections to do this), etc.
>
Actualy this was also discussed with regard to the multiple connection 
points idea - as well as summing inputs we could multiply, average, min, 
max - like I say, you could do all kinds of things.

Colin
